fullText: Williams brings imposing physicality and smoldering intensity to the role of Hickey, the hardware salesman whose arrival at Harry Hope's saloon sets the play's tragic events in motion.
dtliExcerpt: Williams brings imposing physicality and smoldering intensity to the role of Hickey, the hardware salesman whose arrival at Harry Hope's saloon sets the play's tragic events in motion.
bwwExcerpt: The surest way to get as pickled as the self-deceiving regulars at Harry Hope's downtown New York dive bar in The Iceman Cometh would be to take a shot of whiskey every time someone says 'pipe dreams.' Eugene O'Neill was seldom one to go easy on emphatic repetition of his themes, and the playwright's bleak vision of men drowning their deferred plans in cheap booze can be as prolix as it is poetic. George C. Wolfe's revival feels on some levels like it's still cohering, the underlying despair remaining muted for too much of the three-hour-45-minute running time. But it comes together in a powerful final act driven by the searing confessional monologue of Denzel Washington's Hickey.
showScoreExcerpt: Williams brings imposing physicality and smoldering intensity to the role of Hickey, the hardware salesman whose arrival at Harry Hope's saloon sets the play's tragic events in motion.
